James B. Donovan.Action: Insists on precise language to avoid personal bias, repeatedly clarifies that the involved party is 'insured by my client,' not 'my guy.'
Demonstrates patience and willingness to understand the opposing side's explanation despite disagreement and persistent misunderstanding.
Corrects Bates firmly but without hostility, attempts to keep the conversation civil and factual.
Demonstrates clear, logical thinking by challenging the opposing party's claim structure (distinguishing one accident from five claims).
Maintains precise language to clarify roles and responsibilities (correcting 'my guy' to 'insured by my client').
Requests explanation and demands clarity when the argument is unclear ('Five things? Explain it to me.').
Greets his secretary Alison politely with 'Good morning'
Responds to Alison moving an appointment by directly asking 'Why did you do that?'
Acknowledges and confirms a coffee order politely with Watters' secretary Natalie
Engages in casual polite conversation with Lynn Goodnough by asking about his family
Explains liability limits clearly with an analogy about insurance and tornadoes, demonstrating logical reasoning and ability to communicate complex legal points effectively.
Responds promptly and politely to receptionist and secretary; shows awareness of office routine and maintains professional demeanor.
Expresses concern after hearing about an unexpected important matter, indicating situational awareness but possible uncertainty about upcoming events.
Chuckles when joking about his wife's 'homicidal' family holiday visit.
Pauses silently and hesitates to accept defending a despised Soviet spy, showing thoughtfulness and concern about repercussions.
Expresses doubt in criminal law skills but agrees to consider task as an honor, showing sincerity and humility.
Admits he will be publicly reviled for defending the accused, showing honesty and tolerance.
Accepts to defend a despised Soviet spy despite anticipating personal and professional backlash.
Shows a hard look to Doug when he initially balks at working late, then chuckles, indicating a mix of sternness and good-naturedness.
Consoles Carol after she gets stood up, calling the act despicable.
Accepts to defend Abel, a Soviet spy, despite knowing it will cause personal and professional backlash.
Recognizes the importance of the case and discusses it pragmatically with colleagues and family, showing understanding of implications.
Plans ahead by requesting help from junior attorney Doug Forrester and insists on commitment even at personal inconvenience.
Displays confidence and a sense of humor when talking about the case, indicating emotional control and assuredness.
Invites Mary’s sister to join the dinner, showing inclusiveness.
Insists every person deserves a defense and that every person matters.
Corrects family gently when they express hostility toward Abel, maintaining calm and fairness.
Responds with humor to Carol's criticism about dating.
States 'He’s not a traitor, Mary--' in defense of Abel despite family opposition.
Clearly explains the difference between the Rosenbergs as traitors and Abel as not being a traitor because he is not American, demonstrating knowledge and clarity.
Insists on defending a deeply unpopular figure despite social and familial pressure, showing resolve and careful consideration.
Engages calmly with multiple people expressing fear and hostility, managing difficult conversations diplomatically.
Struggles somewhat to convince Mary and others about his position, which may indicate the limits of his persuasiveness in this context.
Insists on the right to a fair defense even for a disliked defendant, emphasizing 'a court of law and not a kangaroo court.'
Welcomes Doug to join dinner and offers meat loaf, showing friendliness to an uninvited guest.
Extends his hand to Mary after an awkward moment but is met with a slap rather than a handshake.
Maintains polite introduction and tries to establish rapport with Abel in detention room, demonstrating respectful and sincere behavior.
Clearly articulates the principle of legal defense, emphasizing the importance of the right to a defense in a court of law rather than supporting espionage.
Maintains focus on the legal principle despite social discomfort and interpersonal tension at the dinner.
Shows slight social awkwardness by misreading the situation with Doug and Mary, leading to an unintended faux pas.
Demonstrates professional formality and confidence introducing himself to Abel with credentials and background, establishing authority.
Watches and tries to read Abel's behavior quietly and carefully, indicating observational skills and situational awareness.
Takes a seat at the table and listens to Abel's story patiently.
Clarifies he is there to serve as Abel’s legal counsel, not government or CIA, emphasizing loyalty to client.
Acknowledges he has not yet represented many accused spies, showing honesty and humility.
Feels duty bound to urge Abel to cooperate with U.S. government despite representing him as counsel.
Listens carefully and asks clarifying questions to Abel, showing patience and control in a tense interrogation setting.
Clearly establishes his role as legal counsel and sets boundaries regarding his relationship with the government and CIA.
Admits he has not yet represented many accused spies, showing honesty but some inexperience.
Assures Abel that he has a mandate to serve him alone despite all others wanting to send him to the electric chair.
Responds with surprise and respect to Abel's polite requests and acknowledgement of mutual humanity.
Confidently sets clear boundaries with Abel, asserting his exclusive mandate to represent him despite difficult circumstances.
Shows measured calm when Abel requests materials that cannot be provided, indicating adaptability and understanding the limits of his role.
Insists on due process for a Soviet spy, despite pressure and skepticism.
Politely corrects Judge Byers regarding the evidence timeline and seriousness of case.
Requests six weeks extension for preparing the defense, acknowledging the volume of evidence and limited resources.
Responds firmly and respectfully to Judge Byers about the seriousness of the case, showing confidence and understanding of legal procedure.
Uses precise language ('allegedly') to maintain professionalism and avoid presumptions in court.
Responds to taxi passing by with frustration but engages another man to gather information.
Stares down a man following him, showing controlled anger and suspicion.
Persists through frustration when a taxi passes him by, calls out assertively, and tries to get another cab despite the rain and difficulty.
Notices he is being followed, experiments with his pace to test the pursuer, uses cover behind a car, controls his breathing, and watches carefully to avoid detection.
When confronted by the man stalking him, stands up, faces the man directly and shows anger rather than fear or embarrassment.
Refuses to violate attorney-client privilege despite pressure, stands firm on ethical principles.
Engages in respectful dialogue, finds common ground emphasizing shared national values.
Maintains confident composure when confronted and asserts his intention to work undisturbed, calmly walks away while eating a peanut.
Questions the validity of the search warrant and insists on seeing the proper legal document.
Argues that even aliens deserve due process of law, citing Supreme Court precedent, defending the rights of a Soviet spy in court.
Engages in casual, somewhat friendly banter with Abel, acknowledging difficult circumstances with mild humor.

Argues in court using established legal precedent (Yick Wo v. Hopkins) to advocate for due process rights for an alien spy, demonstrating knowledge of law and commitment to legal principles despite opposition.
Despite his strong legal argument, his motion is denied by the judge, suggesting limits or challenges in successfully persuading the court.
Maintains a calm and clear demeanor when discussing the case with Abel, showing situational awareness and professionalism.
Listens attentively to his son Roger explaining safety measures and responds supportively.
Expresses reassurance that the danger Roger fears is unlikely to happen.
Listens to his son Roger's safety plan and acknowledges it as good ideas.
Dismisses the possibility of the war beginning and the need for the emergency plan.
Calmly dismisses exaggerated fears of atomic bomb attack, showing confidence and control over the situation.
Engages patiently with Roger’s concerns, listens carefully to the drawing and explanation.
Refuses to engage in emotional or ideological arguments, maintains focus on professional duty despite personal or public opinions.
Appears uneasy or self-conscious when recognized by the public on the subway, potentially indicating vulnerability to public pressure.
Makes a motion to set aside the guilty verdict despite public and jury pressure.
Smiles and reassures Abel about his sentence, showing concern for his wellbeing.
Lights Abel's cigarette and accepts a gift from him, engaging in a friendly and sincere exchange.
Shows tolerance and impartiality by stating he doesn't need to know if Abel is truly a spy, emphasizing the legal principle over personal judgment.
Calls Abel's wife an angel after learning she plays the harp.
Is moved by Abel’s story of the 'Standing Man,' showing empathy.
Greets Millie warmly and compliments her as a 'vision.'
Accepts Millie's offer of Scotch with polite gratitude.
Listens attentively and is visibly moved by Abel's story of resilience, demonstrating empathy and presence of mind.
Engages politely and confidently in social interaction with Millie and Judge Byers, showing ease and composure in social settings.
Politely requests Judge Byers' time at home to discuss broader considerations beyond legal technicalities in the sentencing.
Tries to reason sincerely and pragmatically about the value of keeping Abel alive for possible future prisoner exchange.
Remains composed and respectful despite Judge Byers' sharp interruptions and apparent impatience.
Attempts to persuade the judge to consider broader national interests beyond strict legality by proposing a strategic reason for keeping Abel alive for a potential future prisoner exchange.
Struggles to maintain control of the conversation when interrupted and appears somewhat tentative in advancing his argument under pressure from Judge Byers.
Argues for the humanitarian consideration that the defendant should not die for doing the job they were sent to do.
Smiles when Abel asks about electrocution despite hostile crowd atmosphere.
Acknowledges procedural grounds for appeal calmly amidst tense situation.
Sincerely tries to follow legal principles and uphold constitutional rights despite personal and familial cost.
Gives a helpless look when confronted with concerns about the cost to his family, showing vulnerability and openness.
Engages in respectful, calm dialogue even with hostile or skeptical colleagues.
Argues that there are constitutional grounds for an appeal despite the initial verdict recognizing the defendant as a spy, demonstrating legal knowledge and strategic thinking.
Engages in a reasoned discussion emphasizing the Fourth Amendment issues as strong grounds for appeal.
Refuses to drop the appeal without reasonable grounds, showing confidence and resolve.
Shows some awareness of personal and professional costs but prioritizes legal principles over convenience.
Appears deep in thought when listening to Abel, indicating thoughtful reflection and careful consideration.
Smiles uneasily at Abel's warning, suggesting some internal doubt or worry but not undermining overall competence.
Races to comfort his frightened children, squatting to put an arm around Peggy and reassuring Roger.
Responds calmly and supportively to children after a frightening event, calling the attackers cowards to reassure them.
Insists on protection for his family after an attack, showing concern and care.
Calmly tells the cop to do his job as an officer of the law despite the cop's aggressive tone.
Attempts to de-escalate the situation by suggesting to forget about the rude officer and let the lieutenant handle it.
Slams the front doors shut after returning to the living room with shell-shocked family members.
Addresses the Supreme Court calmly and respectfully, acknowledging the complexity of the Cold War and advocating for fair treatment of Rudolf Abel.
Emphasizes that Abel was subjected to inappropriate treatment despite being a foe, demonstrating concern for human dignity and justice.
Argues that Rudolf Abel deserves full rights despite being an enemy, emphasizing dignity and fairness.
Delivers a reasoned, articulate defense of Rudolf Abel, demonstrating deep understanding of legal principles and moral courage in a Supreme Court setting.
Simply says 'Tired' when asked about losing Supreme Court case, showing restraint and sincerity.
Waves to Watters who looks at him without warmth and does not invite him to join meeting, Donovan passively accepts exclusion.
Responds to Allison about hate mail with light sarcasm ('More hate mail? From Germany now?'), indicating a friendly and somewhat tolerant demeanor.
Stands patiently next to Abel while he reads the letter, showing support silently.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Abel about the letter, showing friendliness and approachability.
Sits quietly staring at the CIA seal, indicating contemplation but no immediate social engagement or warmth.
Politely greets Allen Dulles with respect and gratitude, demonstrating sincerity and courtesy.
Waits patiently with Abel as he reads the letter, demonstrates calm presence in a tense situation.
Engages in thoughtful conversation about next moves despite uncertain circumstances, showing willingness to deliberate and adapt.
Conveys respectful and confident demeanor during introduction to Allen Dulles, showing social and professional competence.
Displays attention to detail by accepting coffee exactly prepared (Nescafe, cream, two lumps), indicating social aptitude and awareness.
Acknowledges the difficult situation with a tone of wry acceptance ('Yeah, I sure did. And I’m so rarely right.'), showing humility and sincerity.
Affirms trustworthiness of Abel by confidently stating 'he won't' give up information, indicating belief in the integrity of others.
Anticipates the possibility of a prisoner exchange, showing foresight.
Acknowledges the complex political fiction around Abel's citizenship and the political sensitivities involved.
Expresses a bit of self-deprecating humor about being right rarely, indicating humility but also confident awareness of the situation.
Accepts the risky negotiation assignment despite lack of official standing and personal clarity, showing willingness to engage without protection or clear support.
Expresses concern about East Berlin being complicated and dangerous, indicating empathy and care for the situation and possibly people involved.
Acknowledges having no client, no wife, no government—shows vulnerability and honesty.
Reaches for Mary, gently holds her waist to comfort her despite the tense situation.
Provides Mary with reassurance that he is doing this for both of them, showing sincerity and care.
Keeps moving without pausing, prioritizing the mission over easing Mary's worries at that moment.
Keeps moving without pausing despite emotional tension, indicating focus and calm under pressure.
Reassures Mary with a meaningful statement 'I am doing this for us' demonstrating emotional intelligence alongside professional resolve.
Engages with complex political-military matters in Berlin showing awareness of uncertain information regarding Soviet contacts and trade negotiations.
Expresses concern and seeks clarity about the situation involving an American student detained by East Germans.
Questions the plan and shows discomfort with uncertainty regarding his escort and safety.
Follows instructions accurately and memorizes critical information quickly when prompted by Hoffman.
Initially hesitates and sighs before handing back the slip of paper instead of immediately memorizing the number as instructed.
Expresses concern for the young man Pryor, noting his age is the same as his associate Dougie.
Questions the dangerous situation he is entering and the potential outcomes for himself.
Asks pointed, relevant questions about potential dangers and outcomes of his mission, showing awareness of risks involved.
Expresses concern and worry based on information from others, indicating thoughtful processing of complex and threatening information.
Summons a degree of sternness and tries to explain his plight in broken German to the soldiers at the checkpoint.
Does not slow down when approached by youths; when confronted, tries to communicate and ultimately cedes his coat without resistance.
Shrugs out of his coat and runs away in freezing weather without conflict.
Steps out of the line at a tense checkpoint and confidently explains his situation in broken German, successfully convincing soldiers to let him pass despite initial suspicion.
Loses his coat to a group of youths without resistance and appears unprepared for this confrontation, ending up freezing in just his suit.
Responds calmly but stiffly to Helen Abel's emotional hug, showing restraint.
Politely greets Rudolf's cousin Drews and the family members, engaging respectfully despite the awkwardness.
Admits confusion about the meeting and clarifies his role, showing honesty and straightforwardness.
Communicates clearly the complexity of the prisoner exchange to Helen Abel, managing expectations realistically.
Maintains composure and corrects mistaken identity politely when introduced to Cousin Drews instead of Mr. Vogel.
Shows some confusion and admits being 'a little... lost' about the meeting agenda.
Clarifies that the exchange for Rudolf cannot happen unilaterally and requires negotiation.
Rises and extends a hand to greet Ivan Schischkin with a dry, urbane manner.
Dubiously watches others comforting a grieving woman without joining in.
Politely and openly engages Schischkin about the terms of the exchange, showing willingness to communicate.
Maintains composure and a dry, urbane manner when meeting a Soviet official under tense circumstances.
Clearly and directly states his purpose—to arrange an exchange of personnel—despite confusion and uncertainty about his contact.
Engages diplomatically by following cues to clear the room for a private discussion, demonstrating social awareness and strategic patience.
Dubiously watches others comfort a tearful woman, showing some skepticism or detachment that may or may not aid in assessing the situation.
Offers a full pardon of Abel to arrange exchange quickly, tries to make the negotiation straightforward and efficient.
Jokes lightly about long country names and the 'Impatient Plan', manages to keep the tone civil and friendly despite tense negotiations.
Firmly insists on simultaneous exchange despite Soviet reluctance, showing resolve but not aggression.
Mentions having a cold and wanting to get home as a reason for impatience, showing sincerity and a humanizing, relatable side.
Clearly states his authority and purpose for negotiating the exchange, showing confidence and clarity.
Insists firmly on a simultaneous exchange despite the other side's suggestion, demonstrating his understanding of leverage and negotiation skills.
Uses humor and light sarcasm (e.g., 'your countries' names are too long', 'call it whatever you want') to ease tension and maintain control of the negotiation.
Mentions having a cold and wanting to go home as a reason for being 'impatient,' which might slightly weaken his negotiating position by revealing personal vulnerability.
Expresses concern for the humane treatment of Abel, hoping he might see the sky again and trade secrets for small favors rather than die in prison.
Encourages Schischkin, a foreign adversary, to have an honest conversation to avoid further mistakes between their countries.
Patiently waits and listens to Schischkin without interrupting or showing hostility during sensitive negotiations.
Shows confidence that arrangements can be made regarding Frederic Pryor’s release, displaying trust in negotiation and goodwill.
Listens attentively to Schischkin despite his low rank and somewhat sarcastic remarks; engages patiently.
Engages politely and calmly with Vogel despite tense political context and underlying hostility.
Does not react defensively or with hostility when Schischkin mocks him about stolen overcoat.
Questions the existence of Mr. Vogel to confirm details before proceeding.
Listens carefully to Vogel’s introduction and tries to understand the status and interests of each party.
Accepts the drink and sits to listen to a potentially important intermediary calmly and respectfully.
Mentions he had his overcoat stolen, showing personal vulnerability but remains composed.
Corrects Vogel about the relationship of Lydia Abel, showing attention to detail and respect for the individuals involved.
Engages in clear, straightforward negotiation emphasizing simultaneous exchange to ensure fairness and protection of all parties.
Shrugs off Vogel’s childish comment with measured composure.
Jokes lightly about losing his coat and being involved in 'spy stuff' when asked by Hoffman.
Shows concern by reminding that there are 'our guys' to consider, including Powers and Pryor, not just Powers alone.
Responds positively to exchange proposal with 'That's swell!'
Shows willingness to consider the location for the exchange, suggesting an alternative for practical reasons

Engages diplomatically with Schischkin to negotiate the location of the prisoner exchange, suggests alternative location for strategic reasons, and agrees to consider the proposed Glienicke Bridge swap.
Offers a contact number to Schischkin in case anything comes up, showing reliability and trustworthiness.
Politely asks Schischkin questions he is not obligated to answer, showing respect and sincerity.
Expresses liking for Schischkin's man and acknowledges his honorable behavior, showing empathy and friendliness.
Pushes gently for information about the man's safety, indicating concern and tolerance.
Arranges a precise meeting time with Schischkin and secures a contact number for urgent communication, showing foresight.
Maintains a calm and polite demeanor while delicately probing sensitive information without pressuring Schischkin.
Recognizes the delicate nature of the subject and acknowledges the uncertainty around Abel's status, demonstrating realistic understanding.
Attempts to understand and engage with Vogel despite cold, dismissive treatment.
Uses a lighthearted remark calling the Soviets 'the Russians' to save time and defuse tension.
Persistently follows Vogel and requests clarification about the situation, showing patience and sincerity.
Attempts to negotiate calmly and logically with Vogel despite Vogel's cold and dismissive attitude.
Fails to fully grasp the political sensitivities Vogel points out, as shown by his casual remark 'Can we just call them “the Russians” -- it’ll save time.'
Persistently follows Vogel to keep the conversation going, demonstrating determination and engagement.
Seemingly underestimates the complexity of the situation by focusing on logical fairness rather than the diplomatic and political realities emphasized by Vogel.
Patiently explains the nature of the prisoner exchange and tries to reassure Vogel that the deal is mutually beneficial, emphasizing cooperation.
Calmly insists there will be no deal without Pryor’s release, showing loyalty and fairness.
Responds respectfully and stays composed even when confronted aggressively by Vogel.
Remains calm and compliant when stopped by police despite tension and nervousness.
Looks to Vogel for cues in a difficult situation, showing trust and tolerance.
Collapses in horror witnessing victims shot at the Wall; visibly devastated.
Orders two breakfasts and multiple coffees from waitress, seemingly isolated and fatigued.
Insists that every person matters and challenges the notion of ignoring the East German message.
Refuses to simply accept the official position and pushes for engagement despite warnings.
Insists on the importance of securing Pryor in the prisoner exchange despite pressure to accept losing him.
Questions and challenges Hoffman's premature assumption that the deal is finalized without Pryor.
Shows readiness and confidence by insisting he will not jeopardize the exchange despite warnings.
No indication of hesitation or doubt, but also no clear strategic moves shown yet.
Lightly teases Hoffman about breakfast after Hoffman objects to Donovan going, showing a friendly and relaxed attitude.
Responds politely and calmly in tense negotiation despite Ott's aggressive pounding on the table and refusal to accept returning Powers, indicating tolerance and sincerity.
Invites the young secretary to sit beside him and speaks to him in a friendly, encouraging manner despite the stressful situation.
Acknowledges the young man's English skills with praise and engages him sincerely.
Attempts to engage the secretary patiently and kindly to communicate despite losing his negotiating partner.
Waits over an hour but remains composed, then quickly adapts to situation by recruiting the secretary as a new interlocutor.
Uses friendliness and clear communication to gain the secretary’s trust and cooperation.
Patiently and kindly confirms secretary understands the important message, calls her 'a good man' to encourage and appreciate her effort.
Jokes lightly ('That’s a long message!') to ease tension despite serious content, chuckles during message delivery.
Insists on clear communication of consequences for Rudolf Abel's wellbeing, showing concern for the prisoner’s mental state.
Expresses desire to get home and rest due to having a cold, but still focuses on completing his duty.
Clearly and precisely communicates a complex message with emphasis and repetition to ensure understanding; gives specific instructions and contingencies to the secretary.
Maintains focus and control despite having a cold; uses humor and seriousness effectively in communication.
Ensures urgency is conveyed by setting deadlines and emphasizing consequences if demands are not met.
Reassures Hoffman despite uncertainty about the exchange outcome, maintains a calm and confident demeanor.
Makes a lighthearted phone call to wife, asking about family and showing interest in personal matters.
Throws an 'evil look' to Hoffman after phone call, indicating some irritation or playfulness towards colleague.
Admits bluntly 'Well then, I have fucked it all up' showing candidness and taking responsibility.
Takes initiative to feel out the situation despite unclear instructions, makes a strategic one-for-one for two proposition to clarify negotiation terms.
Responds confidently and calmly under Hoffman's anger and doubt, showing poise and self-assurance.
Admits the possibility of failure openly but maintains optimism and control of the situation.
Uses a long-distance call in a public place skillfully to communicate discreetly, navigating the risks well.
Appears to disregard strict instructions in favor of his own judgment, which might risk the original deal.
Reacts with enthusiasm and camaraderie when the phone call indicates progress; suggests having a drink to celebrate.
Shows patience and calm uncertainty while waiting for the other side during the exchange; uses polite inquiry ('May I?') before taking binoculars.
Waits patiently and observes carefully alongside Hoffman during tense moments.
Quickly picks up on details, such as noticing snipers in the tower using binoculars.
Expresses confusion or seeks clarification when Hoffman explains the conditions of the exchange.
Shakes Rudolf Abel’s hand warmly and responds 'Happy to see you.'
Shows concern for Abel’s situation by acknowledging the difficulty of identification and hoping it’s not his East German family who identifies him.
Engages Abel in conversation quietly, showing concern about Abel's fate.
Jokes lightly with Abel about his possibly being shot, showing a tolerant and sincere approach to a tense situation.
Does not hesitate to accompany the exchange party to the middle of the bridge despite potential danger, showing trustworthiness and courage.
Takes initiative to open the gate and accompany the exchange party to the middle of the bridge, demonstrating confidence and leadership in a tense situation.
Engages Abel in reflective conversation about the potential outcomes of the exchange, showing thoughtful consideration and emotional intelligence.
Plans to stay on site despite being offered to remain behind, showing resolve and commitment but perhaps exposing himself to risk without clear advantage.
Requests Powers to remove his hat for identification, coordinates with others, and strategically delays exchange to ensure the other man is released first, showing patience and control.
Seems uncertain or requires confirmation about release of another man at checkpoint Charlie, which shows reliance on others but maintains careful verification.
Accepts Abel’s gift, apologizes for not having a gift in return, and regards Abel thoughtfully across the bridge despite tension.
Does not look at Powers when passing on the bridge, maintains a neutral demeanor rather than a warm or friendly one.
Reassures Powers who feels hurt and isolated by affirming the value of his actions.
Greets Mary with a warm embrace, holding her a little closer and longer than usual.
Reassures Powers that what he did matters more than others' opinions, showing emotional intelligence and leadership under pressure.
Receives and recognizes a thoughtful gift (portrait) indicating respect and recognition from others.
Focuses on personal priorities and family upon return, showing balanced attention beyond the mission.
Sleeps exhausted but peacefully after long efforts securing spy exchange.
His family displays emotional pride and relief upon hearing of his role in the exchange.
Does not immediately join family celebrations, retreats quietly to rest.
Stranger on train, formerly disapproving, now recognizes him and smiles.
Smiles back at a woman who once looked at him disapprovingly.
Reflects peacefully yet somberly while looking at children climbing a fence, showing empathy.
Takes on difficult negotiations to secure the release of thousands of prisoners, demonstrating commitment and sincerity toward others' welfare.
Following the successful Powers-Abel exchange, asked by President Kennedy to undertake further complex negotiations, including securing the release of 9,703 prisoners from Cuba.
Appears uncomfortable and contemplative after the exchange, expressing a moment of doubt or reflection.
